title: 107_s610
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Police Gun Buyback Assistance Act" and its purpose is outlined in the findings. Congress finds that a white supremacist used a decommissioned Glock pistol from a law enforcement agency in Washington to shoot children at a Jewish community center in Los Angeles. Additionally, twelve firearms stolen from the Miami-Dade Police Department have been linked to crimes in Chicago, including a shooting near a playground. Over the past 9 years, decommissioned firearms from law enforcement agencies have been involved in multiple incidents. Law enforcement agencies have been involved in over 3,000 crimes, including 293 homicides, 301 assaults, and 279 drug-related crimes. Many departments also resell firearms used in crimes, including assault weapons circulated before the 1994 restrictions. Notable cases include departments in New York, Georgia, Chicago, and other localities. The purpose of this Act is to reduce the number of firearms on the streets by assisting State and local law enforcement agencies in eliminating the practice of transferring decommissioned firearms to any person. The Act aims to reduce firearms on the streets by preventing the transfer of decommissioned firearms to individuals. The Attorney General may provide grants to States or local governments to purchase new firearms and destroy decommissioned firearms, as long as they have a policy against transferring decommissioned firearms to individuals. The Act allows for the transfer of decommissioned firearms to law enforcement agencies, with the requirement for destruction of such firearms. States or local governments receiving grants must use the funds to purchase new firearms only. SEC. 4. APPLICATIONS.

To request a grant under this Act, the chief executive of a State or unit of local government must submit an application to the Attorney General containing required information.

SEC. 5. REGULATIONS. SEC. 5. REGULATIONS. The Attorney General must create regulations within 90 days of the Act's enactment, outlining information and requirements for grant applications. SEC. 6. REPORTING. SEC. 6. REPORTING. A State or local government must report to the Attorney General within 2 years of receiving funds under this Act on its implementation. The report must include budget assurances for law enforcement agencies to purchase firearms without transferring decommissioned ones. SEC. 7. DEFINITION. In this Act, a "decommissioned firearm" refers to a firearm no longer used by law enforcement or involved in a crime and no longer needed for evidence. "Firearm" and "person" have the same meanings as defined in specific sections of the United States Code. Authorization of appropriations for this Act is set at $10,000,000 for each fiscal year from 2001 to 2005.
